paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy in tumors?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Murine tumor models receiving intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy to assess tumor control efficacy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched control groups including vaccine-only treatment, ICI-only treatment, and vehicle controls to establish comparative baselines.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment to assess real-world outcomes stratified by vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of metastatic ICI-treated patients with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination history for comparative analysis.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of metastatic ICI-treated patients without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for baseline comparison.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, introducing potential residual confounding that could affect outcome interpretation.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, creating heterogeneity in treatment sequencing that may influence results.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity across the human cohort limit direct causal interpretation of the vaccination effect.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors due to species differences in tumor biology and immune responses.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings, suggesting context-dependent effects.
